title: 109_s724
content: The Act may be cited as the "No Child Left Behind Reform Act" and includes provisions for Adequate Yearly Progress. The "No Child Left Behind Reform Act" includes amendments to the definition of Adequate Yearly Progress, focusing on academic assessments and measures of individual or cohort growth over time. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 removes certain provisions related to academic assessment and school improvement. SEC. 1120C. Grants for increasing data capacity for purposes of AYP are added to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies to develop data systems for accountability and to help local educational agencies manage information databases. Priority is given to agencies with growth models or proficiency indexes. States must use no more than 20% of grant funds for certain purposes. The section specifies that grant funds must be used for State databases and subgrants to local educational agencies for authorized activities related to measuring adequate yearly progress. Local agencies can use the funds for database upgrades, software/hardware purchases, and hiring staff for data management. The section outlines the use of grant funds for State databases and subgrants to local educational agencies for activities related to measuring student achievement. This includes hiring staff for data management, providing training for staff, principals, and teachers on using data to improve student outcomes. State and local agencies must submit applications to the Secretary and State educational agency, respectively, to receive funding. Targeting transfer options and supplemental services is emphasized in Section 4. Targeting transfer options and supplemental services for students failing to make adequate yearly progress under ESEA, with a focus on maintaining the least restrictive environment for students with disabilities. The Education Act ensures that students with disabilities who transfer under certain provisions are placed in the least restrictive environment. The Education Act allows students transferring to another public school to continue enrollment, with effective dates based on funding appropriations. SEC. 5. DEFINITION OF HIGHLY QUALIFIED TEACHERS. Section 9101(23)(B)(ii) of the Elementary and Secondary Act of 1965 is amended to include requirements for middle school teachers to pass a State-approved middle school generalist exam and obtain a State social studies certificate to teach history and geography. Middle school teachers must pass a State-approved exam and obtain a certificate to teach various subjects such as history, geography, economics, civics, earth science, biology, chemistry, and physics in middle or secondary schools.
